questions.text: A 28-year-old rock climber presents with severe wrist pain and swelling after falling on an outstretched hand. Physical examination shows visible deformity, restricted range of motion, and point tenderness at the dorsal scapholunate interval. The patient reports numbness and tingling in the thumb and index finger. X-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent orthopedic consultation for reduction and stabilization
Immobilization with radial gutter splint and orthopedic follow-up within one week
Discharge with analgesics and orthopedic follow-up in 48â€“72 hours
MRI to further characterize the ligamentous injury pattern

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Carpal dislocations (perilunate, midcarpal, and lunate dislocations) require urgent orthopedic consultation for reduction and stabilization. The presence of median nerve symptoms increases the urgency, as delayed treatment can lead to permanent nerve injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobilization with radial gutter splint and outpatient orthopedic follow-up is appropriate for stable scapholunate dissociation without nerve injury, not for perilunate dislocation with nerve injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Perilunate dislocations, midcarpal dislocations, and lunate dislocations require urgent orthopedic consultation for reduction and immobilization, not discharge. The presence of neurovascular injury makes urgent reduction even more critical to prevent permanent nerve damage.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI may be useful for chronic injuries or when plain radiographs are inconclusive, but acute carpal dislocations with obvious clinical and radiographic findings require immediate surgical consultation, not further imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic repair may be considered in select patients but is not the immediate next step.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who is a construction worker presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after falling from scaffolding and landing on his outstretched right hand. He reports severe wrist pain and numbness in his thumb and index finger. Physical examination shows wrist swelling with visible deformity and point tenderness at the dorsal scapholunate interval. Lateral x-ray shows the capitate dorsally displaced while the lunate remains aligned with the radius. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immobilize with volar-dorsal splint and arrange orthopedic follow-up within 1 week
Administer pain medication and schedule elective surgical repair
Obtain MRI to assess for ligamentous injury before treatment
Obtain urgent CT scan to assess for associated fractures before orthopedic consultation
Consult orthopedics for urgent reduction and long arm splint immobilization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immobilization with volar-dorsal splint and outpatient follow-up is appropriate for scapholunate dissociation without nerve injury, not for perilunate dislocation.

B) INCORRECT:

Delaying treatment is inappropriate for perilunate dislocation, which requires urgent reduction to prevent complications, including permanent nerve injury. The numbness in the median nerve distribution makes urgent intervention essential.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI may be useful for chronic injuries or when x-rays are inconclusive, but this patient has clear radiographic evidence of perilunate dislocation. Treatment should not be delayed for further imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

While CT scan can provide detailed information about associated fractures in perilunate dislocations, this patient's plain radiographs already demonstrate a dislocation requiring urgent reduction. Delaying orthopedic consultation to obtain additional imaging prolongs the time to reduction, potentially worsening median nerve compromise.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Imaging findings of dorsally displaced capitate with lunate remaining aligned with the radius suggest perilunate dislocation. This requires urgent orthopedic consultation for reduction and immobilization with a long arm splint. The numbness suggests possible median nerve involvement, making urgent reduction even more critical.
